name: Saransh Gupta
position: Driving Innovation in Technology and Education | IIT Kharagpur
about: Saransh is an Engineer-II at American Express. He pursued an Integrated Masters Degree from IIT Kharagpur in the Department of Industrial & Systems Engineering in Engineering Product Design. Previously he worked with Amazon as an Applied Scientist Intern, ZS Associates as a Data Science Intern, & Osaka University as a Bioinformatics & Machine Learning Research Assistant. One of his papers is accepted for publication at IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics (JBHI-01644-2021), 2021 & he has presented a research paper at International Conference on Human Interaction & Emerging Technologies: Future Applications 2020 held at Centre Hospitalier Universitaire Vaudois, Lausanne, Switzerland. He firmly believes in leveraging technology, especially the application of Machine Learning & Data Science to solve real-life problems & aspires to build a career in Scientific & Applied Research. He loves to explore new places, interact with people from different walks of life, & practice advanced meditation techniques!

experience.title: Research Assistant

recommendations: Hrishikesh Jadhav “'Machine Learning expert' is the phrase that comes to mind when I think about Saransh. I rarely come across real talents who stand out like Saransh. I had the pleasure of working with him on several projects. I learned so many things from him thanks for all and I owe you for those. As a team member or a super positive person or a saint, Saransh earns my highest recommendation.”
publications: [{"title":"Integrative Network Modeling Highlights the Crucial Roles of Rho-GDI Signaling Pathway in the Progression of Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer","subtitle":"IEEE Journal Of Biomedical & Health Informatics","date":"July 12, 2022","description":"Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is the most prevalent form of lung cancer and a leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide. Using an integrative approach, we analyzed a publicly available merged NSCLC transcriptome dataset using machine learning, protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks and bayesian modeling to pinpoint key cellular factors and pathways likely to be involved with the onset and progression of NSCLC. First, we generated multiple prediction models using various machine learning classifiers to classify NSCLC and healthy cohorts. Our models achieved prediction accuracies ranging from 0.83 to 1.0, with XGBoost emerging as the best performer. Next, using functional enrichment analysis (and gene co-expression network analysis with WGCNA) of the machine learning feature-selected genes, we determined that genes involved in Rho GTPase signaling that modulate actin stability and cytoskeleton were likely to be crucial in NSCLC. We further assembled a PPI network for the feature-selected genes that was partitioned using Markov clustering to detect protein complexes functionally relevant to NSCLC. Finally, we modeled the perturbations in RhoGDI signaling using a bayesian network; our simulations suggest that aberrations in ARHGEF19 and/or RAC2 gene activities contributed to impaired MAPK signaling and disrupted actin and cytoskeleton organization and were arguably key contributors to the onset of tumorigenesis in NSCLC. We hypothesize that targeted measures to restore aberrant ARHGEF19 and/or RAC2 functions could conceivably rescue the cancerous phenotype in NSCLC. Our findings offer promising avenues for early predictive biomarker discovery, targeted therapeutic intervention and improved clinical outcomes in NSCLC."},{"title":"Development of a virtual reality based fire training simulator and machine learning based path guidance system: A case of hospital fire breakouts (IHIET-AI, 2020)","subtitle":"International Conference on Human Interaction & Emerging Technologies: Future Applications 2020"}]
